headline: What's Hot…and Not
summary: A graphical look at how different investments, from REIT shares to crude oil, fared last week.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: CORRECTION
summary: The May 24 Leisure & Arts article "He Makes 'White Rice' Funny" misspelled the name of Steve Carell.

headline: Treasury to Sell $75 Billion
summary: The offerings include $27 billion in three-month bills and $24 billion in 52-week bills.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for May 27, 2011

headline: Biffle? Stooper?  Smoot?
summary: See if you can guess the meaning of some slang words.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Lockheed Network Suffers Breach
summary: Hackers may have infiltrated the networks of top U.S. weapons manufacturer Lockheed Martin, according to a person with knowledge of the attacks.

headline: Mets Lose To Phillies, 6-4
summary: The Mets were one out away from going into the bottom of the ninth inning tied with the Philadelphia Phillies Friday night. But Daniel Murphy allowed a routine ground ball to roll under his glove at first base, leading to a three-run inning for Philadelphia and a 6-4 loss for the Mets.

headline: New York Photos of the Day: May 27
summary: Marines in town for Fleet Week show off their fighting prowess in Times Square, toddlers take in the sun on a Bronx beach, and more in the best images from across Greater New York.

headline: Judge Rules Mladic Can Be Extradited
summary: A Serbian judge ruled that Ratko Mladic, the former Bosnian Serb military commander arrested on genocide charges, is eligible and fit for extradition and should be sent to the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague, but the ex-fugitive's family and lawyers say he is too sick to stand trial.

headline: Honduras' Zelaya to Return on Saturday
summary: Honduras' deposed former President Zelaya, forced out of his country in his pajamas by the army in 2009, is set to return home Saturday under terms of a recent deal between Honduras' government and Zelaya.

headline: Noonan: Word of the Decade: 'Unsustainable'
summary: Washington finally acknowledges the debt crisis. But can it act?

headline: Finding John
summary: A day in the life of Pixar's cartoon king, John Lasseter

headline: Blue Chips Skid for Fourth Week in a Row
summary: The Dow and S&P 500 registered their longest weekly losing streak since February 2010.

headline: Jenkins: How Medicare Was Saved
summary: What a future us will say about the Great Entitlement Fight of 2011.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Michael Barone writing May 26 on state job creation in the Washington Examiner.

headline: Fox Kicks Off Ad Deal-Making for New TV Season
summary: Fox Broadcasting has started to strike some advertising deals for the coming TV season, according to advertising buyers, as the annual upfront marketplace in which buyers commit billions on TV commercials begins to heat up.

headline: Artwork Celebrates Local Businesses
summary: In Park Slope, a neighborhood in Brooklyn, N.Y., some brownstones' stoops carry black-and-white murals of local shop owners and their employees.

headline: Investment Banking 101
summary: None

headline: 3, 2, 1 ... Blastoff!
summary: What does it take to witness a space shuttle launch? The Journal's David Ho found out this spring when he traveled to Florida with his family to see the final launch of Endeavor.

headline: Bears Connect With LinkedIn
summary: Investors paid a premium to go bearish on LinkedIn during the first day of trading in its options, another sign of doubt over the company's stock price.

headline: Photos of the Day: May 27
summary: In today's pictures, riot police scuffle with demonstrators in Spain, Poland rolls out the red carpet for U.S. President Barack Obama, asylum seekers are detained in Indonesia and more.

headline: Crude Holds Above $100
summary: Oil prices settled above $100 a barrel for the third consecutive day, while gasoline futures gained for a sixth day on worries over new refinery outages.

headline: Copper's Streak Continues
summary: Copper futures rose for the fourth consecutive day as a weaker dollar and concerns about supply stoked investment demand.

headline: Gold Ends at Three-Week High
summary: Gold futures ended at their highest levels in more than three weeks, lifted by a weakening dollar and investor demand for a refuge from worries about euro-zone government finances.

headline: Sotomayor Got $1.175 Million Book Deal
summary: U.S. Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor received a $1.175 million book advance last year to write a coming-of-age memoir, according to financial disclosure reports made public on Friday.

headline: McClatchy Sells Miami Herald's Building
summary: Newspaper publisher McClatchy sold the Miami Herald's home for $236 million to Genting Malaysia.

headline: Facebook Beefs Up in Washington
summary: Facebook stepped up its Washington, D.C., presence, hiring two former Bush administration officials to fill out its office in the nation's capital.

headline: Santander Rio IPO to Test Investor Appetite for Argentina
summary: Banco Santander's plan to list the shares of its Argentine subsidiary on the NYSE  will be an important test of investor appetite for exposure to Argentina's fast-growing but unstable economy.

headline: Groups Split Over How to Fight AIDS
summary: A major U.N. declaration on how best to fight the AIDS epidemic is the subject of frenzied jockeying and negotiations, threatening to fracture any consensus on how best to combat the epidemic.

headline: Superagent Andrew Wylie
summary: The agent to Rushdie, Pamuk, Updike and countless other literary luminaries on upholding great writing in an e-reading world.

headline: Unrest in Yemen
summary: As fighting that rocked San'a for the past five days spread beyond the capital on Friday, antigovernment protesters gathered on the weekly day of prayer to protest the leadership President Ali Abdullah Saleh.

headline: Fitch Lowers Japan Outlook
summary: Fitch Ratings lowered its outlook for Japan's burgeoning government debt to negative from stable in a fresh reminder of the economic headwinds buffeting the world's third-largest economy.

headline: Romney Still Leads, but It's Early
summary: JOHN FUND ON THE TRAIL  The presidential candidate got some good news from this week's poll of New Hampshire primary voters, but his lead is clearly tentative.

headline: Banks Lead Europe Higher
summary: European stock markets gained, as bank shares rallied and the Group of Eight said the global economic recovery was gaining strength.

headline: China Information Tech CFO Resigns
summary: China Information Tech said its CFO would resign, sending its shares down in early trading.

headline: Chris Christie's Mixed Message
summary: Gov. Chris Christie embraced yet another hot-button political topic this week, yanking New Jersey from a regional cap-and-trade climate program.

headline: Belarus Ruler Threatens   Government
summary: Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko threatened to fire his prime minister and the head of the country's central bank if they don't find a way to stop runaway growth in consumer prices.

headline: Transferred Inmates Return to Pennsylvania
summary: About 1,100 inmates have returned to Pennsylvania state prisons after spending more than a year in Michigan prisons to ease overcrowding in Pennsylvania's correctional system.

headline: Foot Locker Names New CFO
summary: Foot Locker will rejigger its executive ranks this summer in moves designed to bolster its bifurcated business that will also see it name a new chief financial officer.

headline: GM Nears Human-Resources Hire
summary: General Motors is close to hiring an auto-industry outsider to lead its human-resources operations after government-imposed pay limits slowed the search for months.

headline: Tunisian Leaders Call for Aid
summary: Tunisia's leaders called for aid to maintain the momentum of the "Arab Spring," as economic problems threaten the region's new optimism.

headline: The G-8 in Deauville
summary: Leaders of the Group of Eight industrialized economies gathered Thursday and Friday in the Normandy seaside resort town of Deauville, France.

headline: Ebay Sues Google Over Payments System
summary: EBay and its PayPal unit sued Google over a mobile-payments system, alleging Google used trade secrets eBay developed for competing products.

headline: Royal Bank of Canada's Profit Rises 13%
summary: Royal Bank of Canada boosted its dividend for the first time in almost four years after fiscal second-quarter profit jumped 13%.

headline: Jaguar Land Rover Opens India Plant
summary: Jaguar Land Rover, the U.K.-based unit of Tata Motors, Friday opened its first assembly plant in India, a step that will let the U.K. auto maker intensify its competition with BMW, Daimler and Audi in the country's growing market for luxury vehicles.

headline: G-8 Calls for Gadhafi's Exit
summary: French President Nicolas Sarkozy welcomed Russia's proposal to play a role as a mediator in Libya, but he insisted that any negotiation would be limited to terms of Col. Moammar Gadhafi's departure.

headline: Russian Wheat Export Deadline Nears
summary: The long-awaited return of wheat exports from Russia may be too little, too late, to choke off a 10-week rally that analysts say could lift European wheat prices back to the three-year highs they reached in February.

headline: Japanese Yields Drop
summary: Regular month-end buying of long-term Japanese government bonds by domestic pension funds helped push down yields on Friday, but analysts warned that the direction might reverse in the new week on political uncertainties.

headline: Inflation Edges Lower in German States
summary: Consumer-price inflation in several German states fell slightly on the month during May as energy prices retreated from record levels earlier this year, but remained considerably higher than their 2010 levels.

headline: Foreclosures Weigh on Home Prices
summary: Home prices continued their downward spiral in March as the glut of foreclosures kept a lid on home values.

headline: Cairn-Vedanta Deal Clears Key Hurdle
summary: A panel of Indian ministers Friday recommended the federal cabinet to take a final decision on London-listed miner Vedanta Resources' proposal to acquire a majority stake in Cairn Energy's India unit.

headline: Italy, Spain to Test Bond Markets
summary: Bond auctions in Italy and Spain, together with a likely syndicated issue from the euro zone's bailout fund, will be the key events next week in Europe's sovereign-debt market.

headline: India, The New Luxury Car Hub
summary: Ferrari is the latest luxury car maker to foray into India. A look at the high-end car brands that have entered the Indian market this year, in pictures.

headline: A Milky Dilemma at Parmalat
summary: Groupe Lactalis has offered €2.60 a share for the 71% of Parmalat it doesn't own. Some are holding out for €2.80, but Lactalis seems unlikely to sweeten its offer.

headline: Dexia to Speed Up Restructure
summary: Belgian bank Dexia said it was speeding up its restructuring plan in a move that will reduce its U.S. exposure and improve earnings forecasts but will result in a $5.09 billion hit to its second-quarter results.

headline: Woodside Gas Plan Worries East Timor
summary: East Timor President Jose Ramos-Horta said his country remains concerned about companies' use of "untested technology" to develop major oil and gas resources in the Timor Sea.

headline: Steel Authority Defers Promotional Shows
summary: Steel Authority of India has deferred the promotional shows planned for next week ahead of its follow-on public share offering. A Steel Ministry source says a final decision is yet to be made on the share sale.

headline: Sime Darby Seeks Focus With Sales
summary: Sime Darby will divest its oil and natural gas business and said it will shed more noncore assets as the world's largest listed palm-oil producer looks to bolster profitability.

headline: Ads, Fads and Brand Recall
summary: It's not that unusual to have an advertisement's visual or jingle stuck in your head but you cannot remember the name of the product. Such advertisements score poorly on 'brand recall'.

headline: Skanska CFO: Will Nearly Double Insurance Capacity
summary: Swedish construction company Skanska is getting ready to boost its insurance capacity to enable it to take on more large construction projects in the U.S., the company's new chief financial officer said.

headline: IEA: German Nuclear Halt Poses Carbon Challenge
summary: Germany's moratorium on nuclear-power generation will add around 25 million metric tons a year to the country's carbon-dioxide emissions, which will have to be offset elsewhere, the International Energy Agency said.

headline: India Shares Move Higher
summary: Indian shares rose sharply for a second session Friday as investors hunted for bargains among blue-chip stocks on the first day of the June series of derivatives.

headline: Honda Expects Normal India Production From October
summary: Honda Motor's India unit said it expects vehicle production at its factory to normalize from October onwards, just before a planned introduction of its Brio small car.

headline: EU Vows No Backdown on Basel
summary: The European Union will not back away from implementing new banking rules that cover how much lenders need to hold against possible future losses, said the commissioner responsible for market rules, Michel Barnier.

headline: India Adviser Calls For Opening up Retail
summary: India should allow foreign-direct investment in the multi-brand retail segment as it will help clear supply bottlenecks that fuel inflation, said Chief Economic Adviser Kaushik Basu.

headline: Thoresen Thai Shareholding Under Investigation
summary: Thailand's Securities and Exchange Commission said it will investigate the shareholding of Thoresen Thai Agencies after the commission's chairman was accused of approaching the shipper and demanding the removal of several executives.

headline: MphasiS Profit Drops 19%
summary: MphasiS posted a nearly 19% drop in second-quarter consolidated net profit, hurt mainly by a sharp rise in expenses and slower pace of sales growth that reflected a weakness at its largest client, Hewlett-Packard.

headline: Shanghai, Tokyo Stocks Decline
summary: The Shanghai and Tokyo markets defied broad regional gains, falling 1% and 0.4% respectively, as concerns about inflation restrained buyers.

headline: India Eases Overseas Investment Rules
summary: India's central bank eased some rules governing Indian companies' foreign direct investments, giving them more operational flexibility.

headline: Coal India Eyes Massey's Sidney Mines
summary: Coal India said it is still keen to buy a stake in Massey Energy's Sidney Underground Mines, and is awaiting a response from the U.S.-based company's new management on the potential deal.

headline: Monsoon Delay Won't Hit Sowing
summary: A week-long delay in the arrival of monsoon rains over India's Andaman and Nicobar Islands won't affect planting of summer-sown crops such as rice, pulses and oilseeds, Farm Secretary P.K Basu said.

headline: SpiceJet Net Profit Rises 65%
summary: SpiceJet reported a 65% jump in net profit for the last financial year, as higher load factors and an improvement in air traffic outweighed a steep rise in fuel cost.

headline: Euro-Zone Confidence Data Diverge
summary: Consumers in the 17 countries that share the euro became more upbeat about the economic outlook and the jobs market in May, but businesses became gloomier, with manufacturers reporting a drop in export orders.

headline: Yandex Underwriters Exercise Full Overallotment Option
summary: Russian internet-search engine Yandex said its initial public offering underwriters have exercised in full the overallotment option for $130.4 million.

headline: Kazakhmys Approves Hong Kong Secondary Listing
summary: U.K.-listed copper miner Kazakhmys said its board of directors has approved a secondary listing of the company's shares in Hong Kong to be completed by the end of June.

headline: Indian Nationals Advised to Leave Yemen
summary: India's foreign ministry has advised all Indian nationals living in Yemen to leave the country after a sharp escalation in violence between soldiers loyal to President Ali Abdullah Saleh and tribesmen calling for him to resign.

headline: Deutsche Bank Banker Arrested in Hong Kong
summary: A senior Deutsche Bank investment banker was arrested at Hong Kong's airport last week for possession of an unlicensed firearm.

headline: North Korea Says It Will Free American
summary: North Korea will release a U.S. salesman  it arrested last November for an unspecified crime, the North's state media said.

headline: Sony to Partially Restart PlayStation Network in Asia
summary: Sony will partially restart its PlayStation Network online videogame service and its Qriocity online music service in Japan and other parts of Asia.

headline: iPhone 4 Hits India
summary: Promotion campaigns by Aircel in Hyderabad and the midnight launch of the iPhone 4 in New Delhi and Chennai.

headline: China Development Bank to Buy TPG Stake
summary: China Development Bank confirmed Friday it plans to buy a minority stake in San Francisco-based private equity fund TPG Holdings, but said the deal requires government approval.

headline: The Cairn-Vedanta Deal So Far
summary: London-based Cairn Energy agreed to sell a majority stake in its India holdings to Vedanta Resources. However, the deal struck last August got caught in a classic bureaucratic tussle. A key ministerial panel is expected to meet Friday to take a call on the deal.

headline: Japan's Ozawa Challenges Kan
summary: Political power broker Ichiro Ozawa said he is ready to take on Prime Minister Kan for what he sees as the government's mishandling of the nuclear crisis.

headline: Honda Sees Higher Asia, Oceania Production in July
summary: Honda Motor expects its production volume in Asia and Oceania to start picking up in July as the supply of parts from Japan gradually increases, the auto maker's Asian Honda Motor unit said. Also, auto production in Japan in April was down monumentally from a year earlier.

headline: Taiwan Plans to Expand Banks' Yuan Scope
summary: Taiwan's financial regulator said it plans to expand the scope of offshore yuan business for the island's banks in a bid to get a larger slice of the yuan business as China progressively internationalizes its currency.

headline: The Unappetizing Side of Britannia
summary: Britannia Industries is morphing from a sleepy Bangalore-based biscuit maker to a dynamic conglomerate with an array of products that span the entire food chain.

headline: U.K. House Prices Rise Modestly
summary: U.K. house prices rose modestly in May, with the market expected to stay subdued for the remainder of 2011 as household budgets remain under pressure, mortgage lender Nationwide Building Society said.

headline: Crompton Greaves Buys U.S. Firm for $30 Million
summary: Crompton Greaves has acquired U.S.-based QEI, a provider of automation systems and products for power transmission and distribution, for an enterprise value of $30 million.

headline: Saving the Secret Towers
summary: Across the remote regions of western Sichuan and Tibet, there are hundreds of rock towers, some of which date back as far as 1,700 years and stand up to 50 meters tall. A small number of preservationists are striving to save the towers.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: Indian gypsies at the Khamoro Festival in Prague, prayers in the Hazratbal Shrine in Srinagar and more.

headline: Genting's Singapore Project Sees Difficulty
summary: Malaysia-based casino operator Genting said its first-quarter profit rose, while construction may be delayed on its Resorts World Sentosa project in Singapore.

headline: Regulatory Burdens on Hiring Targeted
summary: The White House outlined the plans federal agencies submitted to streamline or eliminate an array of federal rules following a review ordered by Obama in response to complaints that regulatory burdens were discouraging hiring.

headline: MCap's Fund Picks Up 1% Stake in Jyothy Labs
summary: Emblem FII, a fund advised by MCap Fund Advisors Pvt. Ltd., has picked up a 1% stake in Jyothy Laboratories Ltd. from the open market. At current market price, the investment is valued at about $5 million.

headline: China Explosions Kill Three
summary: Chinese authorities say a man, apparently angry about property redevelopment, set off three blasts at government offices in a city in southeastern China, killing himself and two other people.

headline: Congress OKs Patriot Act Extension
summary: Congress passed legislation that renews three key provisions of legislation granting law enforcement officials authority to conduct surveillance on suspected terrorists.

headline: New Life for Second Jet Engine
summary: The House passed a defense-authorization bill that keeps alive GE's hopes to build an alternate engine for the F-35 joint strike fighter, undercutting the chamber's own efforts to cut government spending.

headline: A House of Alternative Energy
summary: Widespread Panic lead singer and guitarist John "JB" Bell and his wife get good vibes at their home and wellness center in a tiny mountain town in Georgia.

headline: Zee, Star India Form TV Distribution Venture
summary: Zee Entertainment Enterprises and Star India have formed a joint-venture company to distribute their television channels in India.

headline: Homes Near Art Museums
summary: Tour three apartments near modern art museums in San Francisco, Calif., New York and Los Angeles.

headline: Meet Brooklyn's Next First Lady
summary: With the news that Kim Kardashian is engaged to be married to the Nets' Kris Humphries, the possibilities for coy self-promotion, 21st century shamelessness and unstoppable entrepreneurial might are endless.

headline: Flamenco Singer El Cigala Relaxes at Home
summary: When he isn't singing to the beat of the flamenco, Latin Grammy-winner Diego Jimenez Ramon Salazar, or el Cigala, relaxes at home with his kids in front of the PlayStation 2.

headline: Jeff Wall's 'Crooked Path'
summary: As a new retrospective of his work opens in Brussels, photographer Jeff Wall explains how his creative process is a "crooked path" of surprises and accidents.

headline: Strauss-Kahn's Many New York Abodes
summary: Finding a house for house arrest has not been easy for former International Monetary Fund director Dominique Strauss-Kahn. A look at his various accommodations in New York City.

headline: Jennifer Lawrence: Unnerved by a Taste of Fame
summary: Recently tapped for the starring role in "The Hunger Games," the "Winter's Bone" actress talks about growing up, hating school, getting discovered and having doubts.

headline: Tiffany Sales Growth Tops Expectation
summary: Tiffany's earnings jumped 26%, topping the company's own guidance, as it continued to post double-digit sales growth. The jeweler also raised its full-year earnings estimate, saying sales growth is exceeding expectations.

headline: Pensions Leap Into Hedge Funds
summary: Public pension plans are stepping up investments into hedge funds, seeking to boost returns despite losses they suffered in some funds in the global financial crisis.

headline: Philip Morris Looks to Nicotine Aerosol
summary: Philip Morris bought the global patent rights to a new technology that delivers nicotine to users' lungs but doesn't involve smoking. The patent covers a technology that delivers a nicotine-infused aerosol.

headline: Dollar Falls Against Euro
summary: Faltering U.S. economic growth and gloomy labor market data undercut the dollar, momentarily overshadowing the euro-zone debt crisis.

headline: Fiat to Acquire Majority of Chrysler
summary: Fiat said it plans in the next 10 days to buy the U.S. Treasury's 6% stake in Chrysler, giving it majority control of the auto maker and raising questions about whether Chrysler will go ahead with a public offering of shares.

headline: Have Our Cultural Stewards Abandoned One of Their Own?
summary: It's irresponsible to argue that we must abide by China's blatant violation of human rights.

headline: The Third Life of a 'Half-Amateur'
summary: Embarking on what he calls "my third life," cellist Mischa Maisky is seeking "to find a balance" between career and family—and beginning to find that balance by taking his musician children on the stage and on tour with him.

headline: Alipay Receives China License
summary: Chinese payment-services firm Alipay received a license from the country's central bank to operate under new rules requiring such providers to be locally held.

headline: Ted Osborn: Hidden Weakness in China's Banks
summary: A nonperforming loans problem may be festering at the largest Chinese banks, even though the official numbers say otherwise.

headline: Love Bites: Show With a History
summary: The new NBC series about sex, dating and marriage has a tangled history.

headline: Are the Other Boeing Workers' Rights Lost?
summary: Regarding Arthur Laffer and Steve Moore's "Boeing and the Union Berlin Wall" (op-ed, May 13): Do not Boeing's South Carolina employees, who recently chose to exercise their legal right to decertify the union, have the right not to be retaliated against by their own former union?

headline: Strauss-Kahn Defense Offers Hints on Strategy
summary: Former IMF chief Dominique Strauss-Kahn's lawyers gave a small glimpse into a defense strategy in his sex-assault case: focus on the alleged victim.

headline: Poker With Einhorn Is Risky Business
summary: When told that David Einhorn is a poker player, Mike Pelfrey, an avid card player himself, said, "Tell him to come to the back of the plane—bring his wallet."

headline: David Mermelstein: Silent Films, Silent Sorrow
summary: A collection of Mikio Naruse's earliest movies, where the Japanese auteur poignantly portrays thwarted hopes and compromised dreams.

headline: Rooftop Terraces Are Raising the Bar
summary: A slew of rooftop bars have opened across Germany in the past few years, offering sun-seeking patrons an elegant downtown alternative to the oompah of a shady beer garden.

headline: China Bought U.S. Corn
summary: The U.S. government confirmed that exporters struck deals to sell corn to China, fueling expectations the Asian nation will be a customer whenever prices for the commodity dip.

headline: G-8 Leaders Focus on Mideast
summary: Leaders of the Group of Eight expressed confidence in the rebounding global economy Thursday and said they were working on an ambitious aid program for "Arab Spring" countries.

headline: Palin Sets Tour With Stop in New Hampshire
summary: Palin will launch a tour of the East Coast on Sunday that includes a stop in New Hampshire, a move likely to roil the GOP presidential nominating contest.

headline: How the Yankees Play the Market
summary: More than any other in recent history, this Yankee team was built on the labors of director of pro scouting Billy Eppler and his team of scouts.

headline: The Church on Catfish Row
summary: It's nothing like the "Porgy and Bess" envisioned by George Gershwin and his collaborators; but the version now staged at Chicago's Court Theatre is so emotionally true to the spirit of the piece that any lingering reservations will be quickly swept away.

headline: HSBC Plans Course Correction
summary: HSBC CEO Stuart Gulliver will have to explain why "The World's Local Bank" won't be nearly so local going forward when he faces shareholders at the bank's annual meeting.

headline: What's on Around Europe
summary: The Weekend Journal's guide to exhibitions, concerts and events across Europe.

headline: The Art World's Olympics
summary: The Venice Biennial is the Olympics of the contemporary art world, a century-old event in which countries send their most promising artists to exhibit in pavilions and palazzos across the watery city.

headline: Serbia Arrests Fugitive Gen. Mladic
summary: Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb general accused of genocide for the 1995 massacre of some 8,000 unarmed Muslim men at Srebrenica, was captured in Serbia after a decade and a half on the run as one of the world's most wanted war criminals.

headline: Juncker: Greece Aid in Question
summary: A top euro-zone policy maker suggested the IMF may withhold its next payment on Greece's bailout, forcing Europe to scramble to plug the gap.

headline: 'Lost' and Found
summary: Alumni of the ABC show "Lost" are returning in force to new TV shows. Here's where they'll be turning up.

headline: Burger Battle Heats Up
summary: Go Burger, the latest outpost of the popular BLT group of restaurants, has thrown its hat into the ring for best burger on Manhattan's Upper East Side.

headline: Options Traders Salivate Over LinkedIn
summary: Investors are expected to pile into bearish puts on the business-networking company's stock after last week's initial public offering.

headline: Recently Reviewed
summary: 'A Minister's Wife' at New York's Lincoln Center

headline: Capturing the Ethnic Cleanser
summary: Ratko Mladic finally faces justice.

headline: Chamber Wary of Cybersecurity Plan
summary: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce is rejecting as "regulatory overreach" the core of a new White House proposal for protecting America's computer systems, according to an internal draft document.

headline: The Strauss-Kahn Standard
summary: Why the IMF overlooked DSK's sexual marauding, and the vindication of Paul Wolfowitz.

headline: Homes Near Art Museums -- Photos
summary: Tour apartments in San Francisco, New York and Los Angeles priced around $1.5 million.

headline: Aiding Mental Health After Prison
summary: The Fortune Society has always lacked is an outpatient mental-health clinic providing post-incarceration psychotherapy. That's where the Jacob & Valeria Langeloth Foundation comes in.

headline: Investors Assail Deutsche Bank on Succession, Stock
summary: Deutsche Bank's senior management was called to task at the German bank's annual shareholder meeting for failing to articulate a clear succession plan.

headline: Starlets and Presidents
summary: Elliot Erwitt, now 82, finds intimate moments in many places, including history. Plus, "Franklin & Bash," on TNT, and more.

headline: 999 Appearances Later, Mo's Still the Same
summary: He was essentially the same pitcher in appearance No. 1, against the California Angels on May 23, 1995, as he was in appearance No. 1,000, against the Toronto Blue Jays on May 25, 2011.

headline: A Little Bit of Tuscany in Kansas
summary: Tour this 5,874-square-foot home with four bedrooms, three full baths and two half-baths, asking $4 million.

headline: Transplants and the First Amendment
summary: J. Gordon Melton's "Religious Freedom & Bloodless Liver Transplants" (houses of Worship, May 13) does a masterful job at painting a distorted picture of Jehovah's Witnesses. What should a person do when the laws of man conflict with the laws of God?

headline: Hundreds Flee Gun Battle in Mexico
summary: Three days of gunbattles this week between rival drug gangs in Michoacán state killed an unknown number of people, forced hundreds to flee, and raised fresh fears that another major Mexican state has become all but ungovernable.

headline: A Swinging Copenhagen
summary: Copenhagen, already one of Europe's most relaxed capitals, sheds what is left of its inhibitions in early July, when just about the entire city is taken over by the annual Copenhagen Jazz Festival.

headline: U.S. Gains Entry to bin Laden's House
summary: Under a new agreement with Pakistan, Central Intelligence Agency forensics experts will begin scouring Osama bin Laden's residence for hidden clues to the activities of al Qaeda and its late leader.

headline: Singers' Union to Opera: Halt
summary: The union representing New York City Opera singers and production personnel filed charges with the National Labor Relations Board, a move that has the potential to derail the company's plans to leave Lincoln Center for a less expensive venue.

headline: Army Head Likely Joint Chiefs Pick
summary: Army Gen. Martin Dempsey is the likely White House pick to become chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, a position that would require him to wind down combat operations after 10 years of war and absorb large budget cuts without losing the military's edge.
